entry.content:
Python 3.11 æ–°åŠŸèƒ½

åŸæ–‡: PyCoder's Weekly - Issue #482

  • 210721 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 42 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆå¿«è¯‘
  • 210721 Zoom.Quiet(å¤§å¦ˆ) ç”¨æ—¶ 37 åˆ†é’Ÿ å®Œæˆæ ¼å¼è½¬æŠ„.
  • ç”¨Fastapiæ„å»ºPython Web APIs
    • REAL PYTHON

In this guide, written by FastAPI creator SebastiÃ¡n RamÃ­rez, youâ€™ll learn the main concepts of FastAPI and how to use it to quickly create web APIs that implement best practices by default. By the end of it, you will be able to start creating production-ready web APIs.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • å¹•å/ Pythonå¯¼å…¥ç³»ç»Ÿçš„å·¥ä½œåŸç†
    • VICTOR SKVORTSOV

Importing a Python module is probably one of the most used language features. But Pythonâ€™s import system remains a mystery to many Python developers, even folks with years of experience. This in-depth article explores how the import system works from the top down. Youâ€™ll learn everything from the difference is between absolute and relative imports to how Python searches for modules and packages and resolves naming conflicts.

  • å…¨èŒ CPYTHON å¼€å‘å•†å‘¨æŠ¥
    • ÅUKASZ LANGA

After years of fundraising efforts, the Python Software Foundation finally hired their first CPython Developer-In-Residence. Åukasz Langa reports on what he accomplished during his first week on the job, how heâ€™s finding a balance between the various tasks required of him, and what his plans are for next week. Heâ€™s included a full detailed log of everything accomplished with links to GitHub issues and pull requests.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

Å <- æ€ä¹ˆå¿µ? 7 ?

)

  • Python 3.11 æ–°åŠŸèƒ½
    • PYTHON.ORG

Python 3.10 is still in beta, but work on Python 3.11 has already begun. Big changes include some major improvements to tracebacks as well as a new cube root function in the math module.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

å—¯å“¼, å…ˆç”¨ Py3.11 é‡å†™ PyPI ?

)

  • Coverage 6.0 Beta 1 å‘å¸ƒ

æ¢è®¨/åç³Ÿ

Discussions

  • NumPyic æ–¹æ³•å¯¹ NDARRAY è¿›è¡Œé¡ºæ—¶é’ˆæ’åº
    • STACK OVERFLOW

There might not be too many applications for this, but the accepted solution to this Stack Overflow question is pretty slick and features a NumPy array method that you might have glossed over: .rot90().

æ–‡ç« /æ•™ç¨‹/å—¯å“¼

Articles, Tutorials and Talks

  • ç”¨ python è¿›è¡Œè¯­éŸ³è¯†åˆ«
    • REAL PYTHON
    • course

In this course, youâ€™ll cover the fundamentals of speech recognition with Python. Youâ€™ll learn which speech recognition library gives the best results and build a full-featured â€œGuess The Wordâ€ game with it.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • åœ°å›¾ä¸Django/ Geodjangoï¼ŒPostgiså’Œä¼ å•
    • PAULO MELCHIORRE

This quickstart guide shows you how to create a web map using Djangoâ€™s GeoDjango module. Data for the map is stored in a PostgreSQL database using the PostGIS extension, and Leaflet, a lightweight JavaScript library for interactive maps, is used on the front-end. Youâ€™ll not only learn how to set up the Django application and display the map but also add markers to the map and automatically center the map on the application userâ€™s location.

  • Python è¯­è¨€å³°ä¼šä¸Šè§„åˆ’æœªæ¥å¿…é¡»æ›´å¿«
    • REAL PYTHON
    • podcast

Do you wonder what the future may hold for the Python language? Are there speed improvements coming soon? What if you could be in the room while the core developers discuss Pythonâ€™s future? This week on the podcast, we have Joanna Jablonski, who was invited to the Python Language Summit 2021 as a journalist to summarize and document the event.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • äº†è§£django/å¼„æ¸…æ¥š Settings
    • MATT LAYMAN
    • â€¢ Shared by Matt Layman

All Django apps need to be configured in order to run properly. This article walks you through how the Django settings file works and how it is organized. Youâ€™ll learn about environment variables and how to use them in your settings. Youâ€™ll also see some patterns for dealing with settings in different environments, such as development, testing, and production, as well as some tools for monitoring and managing Django settings.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

Settings è™½å¥½, ä¸å¯è´ªæ¯...

)

  • Python ç¤¾åŒºé‡‡è®¿/ Dustin Ingram
    • REAL PYTHON Dustin Ingram is a developer advocate at Google, a director of the PSF, and a maintainer of PyPI. In this interview, Dustin talks about how Googleâ€™s use of Python might differ from your own, maintaining PyPI, his love of PyCons and cooking, and more.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • æ— æœåŠ¡å™¨ django apis ä¸ aws lambda å’Œ zappa
    • JEKAYINOLUWA OLABEMIWO
    • â€¢ Shared by Robertino

Hosting serverless apps on AWS can be a lot of work if you set everything up manually. The Zappa project makes configuring and deploying a serverless app on AWS Lambda a cinch! This tutorial walks you through creating a Django REST API and deploying it to AWS Lambda with Zappa step-by-step. Youâ€™ll even learn how to set up authentication using Auth0!

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

entry.content:

Learn how a bug was born â€” one that resulted in hundreds of users of an application getting a notification that they had been paid when in fact they had not! In this story, Haki Benita shares how a slip-up with Django signals caused him and his team quite a headache. Youâ€™ll learn how the application was architected, how the bug occurred, and how they fixed it, along with some other remedies to consider.

What does Python packaging look like in 2021? What are the best tools to use? In this article, youâ€™ll see one developerâ€™s opinion about the state of Python packaging in 2021, what tools they are using the most often, and some thoughts on how the situation can continue to improve moving forward.

June 2021 was full of notable events in the Python world! In this article, youâ€™ll get caught up on whatâ€™s been happening with Python during this past month, including some changes at the Python Software Foundation and the announcement of a new recipient of the PSF Fiscal Sponsorship Program.

Are you ready to expand your Python knowledge into the intermediate to advanced territory? What tools are awaiting your discovery inside Pythonâ€™s functools module? This week on the Real Python Podcast, David Amos is back, and heâ€™s brought another batch of PyCoderâ€™s Weekly articles and projects.

  • Pyflyby: æé«˜ Jupyter äº¤äº’å¼ä¼šè¯æ•ˆç‡
    • MATTHIAS BUSSONNIER
    • AND AARON MEURER

Thereâ€™s a new tool in town that aims to improve Python developer focus and minimize distractions while coding, especially in Jupyter Notebooks. That new tool is pyflyby, and it can handle tidying up and collecting imports and exports from Python modules. For example, in a Jupyter Notebook, pyflyby can automatically import the right modules and functions from NumPy if you use something in a cell without importing it first.

  • Copilot /ç”¨ Python ç¼–å†™çš„æ–‡æœ¬æ¸¸æˆ
    • SAGINDYK URAZAYEV

GitHubâ€™s new Copilot feature has a lot of people talking. The projectâ€™s goal is to be an AI pair programmer â€” a tool that can suggest entire lines of code or even entire functions! In this amusing article, one developer who gained access to Copilotâ€™s technical preview shares how the AI wrote an entire text-based adventure game that turned out to be the solution to an exercise from a Python instructional book.

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

TUI/CLI æ°¸è¿œæ˜¯ç¨‹åºçŒ¿è‡´äº², ä¼˜å…ˆæŠ˜è…¾, æ²¡æ¯›ç—…,

å—¯å“¼, VSCode å‡ºé•œç‡è¶Šæ¥è¶Šé«˜,

"workbench.colorTheme": "Solarized Dark"

ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æœ€å¸¸è§çš„...

)

  • æ›´å‹å¥½çš„ Tracebacks åœ¨ REPLs (åŒ…å« Jupyter)
    • ANDRÃ‰ ROBERGE

Tracebacks are often the start of any Python debugging journey. But tracebacks can be difficult to read and confusing to beginners. The friendly-traceback project aims to lift the veil of confusion for tracebacks by providing more helpful error messages with lots of context. New updates to the project include better tracebacks in Jupyter Notebooks!

(æ˜¯ä¹Ÿä¹:

)

  • å¹³æ–¹æ ¹å‡½æ•°åœ¨ Python
    • REAL PYTHON
    • course

In this quick and practical course, youâ€™ll learn what a square root is and how to calculate one in Python. Youâ€™ll even see how you can use the Python square root function to solve a real-world problem.
